Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10157 Health services; policies and procedures
Section (1) A facility shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures that address all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The facility accepted placement of a youth being aware of the
youth's prescribed medications. Unknown to the youth, DHHS,
and the youth's mother, the facility refused to give the youth their
prescribed psychotropic medication without consulting a doctor.
The facility did not titrate or wean the youth off the medication as
required.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on May 8, 2025,
in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Complainant said Youth
A’s behaviors have decompensated severely since stopping his
medications. Complainant said Youth A’s medication was
discontinued without being weaned off resulting in him not being
able to sleep and being increasingly agitated resulting in many
behavioral issues.
2

Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on May
13, 2025. Youth A said he is prescribed Seroquel for Borderline
Personality Disorder, and Multiple Personality Disorder. Youth A
said he was provided Seroquel for the first two days at Saginaw
Detention. However, when Nurse came into work on the following
Monday, she discontinued Seroquel, and he has not been
provided with it since. Youth A said the doctor that prescribed him
Seroquel told him he cannot stop taking it as it will be harmful to
him. Youth A denied being given any other medication in place of
the Seroquel and denied being weaned off it slowly. Youth A said
after being taken off Seroquel he was having hot/cold sweats,
hallucinations, and did not sleep for three to four days. Youth A
said he is also prescribed Adderall twice per day and was not
consistently getting his afternoon dose.
Staff 5 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on May 21,
2025, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 5 said he
does not dispense Youth A’s medications. Staff 5 said he has
heard Youth A refuse to take his medications due to them not
providing him with “all his meds”. Staff 5 said he is unsure what
medications Youth A is not being given. Staff 5 denied seeing
Youth A have any withdraw symptoms. Staff 5 said Youth A is
capable of advocating for what he needs and will do so often.
Staff 2, Staff 6, Staff 7 and Staff 8 were interviewed face-to-
face at the facility on May 21, 2025, in collaboration with
MDHHS Worker. Staff 2, Staff 6, Staff 7, Staff 8 said they do not
have any knowledge of Youth A’s medications. Staff 6 and Staff 7
said they have not seen Youth A going through any withdrawals.
Staff 9 and Staff 10 were interviewed via telephone on June 2,
2025, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 9 and Staff 10
said they have seen Youth A be given medications; however, they
have never dispensed the medications and is unsure what Youth
A is prescribed. Staff 9 and Staff 10 said he has not seen Youth A
have any withdraw symptoms and has not seen or heard of any
sleeping issues he is experiencing.
Staff 12 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on May 21,
2025, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 12 said he
has provided Youth A medications on occasion and each time
Youth A would make a comment that he was supposed to have
additional medications that he was not being provided with but
never told him the name of the medication. Staff 12 said Youth A
would sometimes refuse his medications. Staff 12 said he has not
3

seen or heard of Youth A having any withdrawal symptoms,
including hot/cold sweats, shaking, or sleeping issues.
Staff 13 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on May 13,
2025, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. A follow-up
interview was conducted face-to-face at the facility on June
17, 2025. Staff 13 said Youth A arrived at the facility on April 17,
2025, and during the intake process he reported he receives
multiple medications and is schizophrenic. Staff 13 said Youth A’s
medications came in the original bottles. Staff 13 took them and
contacted Nurse to notify her of what medications Youth A was
taking. Nurse provided directions on when and how to dispense
the medications. Staff 13 said she provided Youth A a night
medication the first night he was there however Nurse came into
the facility the next day and Youth A no longer had a nighttime
medication. Staff 13 said she was not part of determining what
medications Youth A would remain on or discontinue. Staff 13 said
Youth A never complained to her about not getting his
medications, never said he was unable to sleep, and she did not
notice any signs of withdrawals with Youth A. Staff 13 said Youth
A is very capable of verbalizing anything he needs and advocating
for himself. Staff 13 said Youth A told her that he has a second
personality “Bob” that comes out whenever he is stressed,
however she denied seeing this personality.
Nurse was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on May 21,
2025, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Nurse said she is
employed by Wellpath, which is a company contracted to provide
medical treatment to the youth at Saginaw Detention Center.
Nurse said Youth A was placed at the detention center on the
weekend and Staff 13 called to notify her of the placement and
medications. Nurse said Doctor was out of the country at that
time, so no medication changes were made over the weekend.
Nurse said that when she arrived to work on the following
Monday, she reviewed Youth A’s medications and “packed them”
for daily distribution. Nurse reported she contacted Doctor who
discontinued Youth A's Seroquel but made no other changes.
Nurse said Seroquel is a “non-formulary” medication that Wellpath
does not prescribe. Nurse said she was told Seroquel is a sleep
medication and they do not treat sleep issues. Nurse said Youth A
was prescribed Adderall in the morning and afternoon, however
for the first week of his placement she did not realize he had the
afternoon dose and did not provide it to him. Nurse said once she
caught her error, Youth A was given the second dose of Adderall.
Nurse said Youth A did not come to the facility with enough
Adderall to last 30 days, so she was working with Foster Care
4

Worker on getting a refill. Nurse said Foster Care Worker told her
since Youth A was no longer in their county the prescribing doctor
would not issue refills. Nurse said Foster Care Worker suggested
using Saginaw County CMH however CMH said due to Youth A
being placed in the detention that is considered a “short stay”, and
they would not add him to their caseload to prescribe him
medications. Nurse said Doctor was not willing to refill the
Adderall because it is a controlled substance. Youth A was only
going to be there a short time so there would be no follow up, and
Doctor is not a psychiatrist. Nurse said Youth A is not going to
school at the facility and so “does not really need it.” Nurse said
Youth A is also prescribed Zyprexa as a PRN and has been taking
that at nighttime.
Doctor was interviewed via telephone on June 2, 2025, in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Doctor said he was unable
to discuss client specific concerns due to confidentiality, however,
was willing to discuss the processes that are used at Saginaw
Detention Center. Doctor said he is employed through Wellpath
and contracted to provide medical services at Saginaw Detention
Center. Doctor said Seroquel is not on the formulary list and
therefore not approved for his distribution. Doctor said the
contracted pharmacy they use does not carry Seroquel as it is
used as a sleep aid and not FDA approved for use in children.
Doctor said Nurse sends him a list of medications that youth are
prescribed, and he gives the directive for which medications are
given to the youth. Doctor said there are no withdrawal symptoms
from ending Seroquel so there would be no issue stopping it
abruptly. Doctor said all psychiatric care would need to be done
through a psychiatrist as he only sees youth for medical issues
such as well-child exams and minor injuries. Doctor said he would
not prescribe or refill a prescription for Adderall as that would need
to be done through a psychiatrist.
Documents Reviewed:
• Offender Note for Youth A was reviewed. The note was
dated April 22, 2025, and stated “Pt takes Seroquel 25mg
QAM and Seroquel 400mg QHS [Doctor] will not continue
the Seroquel while in the facility. This is a drug we don’t
give.”
• Medication Administration Record for Youth A was
reviewed. Youth A was not provided with his 12pm dose of
Adderall 15mg from April 17, 2025, until May 10, 2025.
Youth A’s Adderall prescription ran out on May 15, 2025,
and was not refilled during his placement at Saginaw
Detention which ended on May 21, 2025.
5

• A review of the FDA website showed Seroquel is approved
for adolescents ages 13-17.
• A review of Wellpath “Formulary Medication” document was
reviewed. The documented included all of the approved
medications and Seroquel was not included on that list. The
document outlines how Wellpath determines which
medications are included on the list which states, “We
concur and evaluate medications for the formulary based
on use, effect, and adverse drug effects to promote rational
cost-effective use in the population(s) that we serve.” In
addition, there is a process outlined for the use of non-
formulary medications which states, “Non-formulary
medication requests and rationale for use (completed by
prescriber) are reviewed by a Wellpath Regional Medical
Director, The Chief of Psychiatry for Corrections, or his
designee. These requests will either be: approved; returned
with an alternative recommendation for; or there will be a
request for additional information in order to further
evaluate.”
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per staff and youth
interviews and documentation review, Youth A was not provided
his Adderall as prescribed between April 17, 2025, and May 10,
2025, and then again after May 15, 2025.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
Technical assistance was provided for Saginaw Detention Center
to explore options for youth psychiatric care. Wellpath indicated
psychiatric care would need to be done through a psychiatrist as
Wellpath only sees youth for medical issues. There is concern
youth are admitted into the short-term program and although
Wellpath indicated they do not provide psychiatric care, they do
discontinue medications and do not refill previously prescribed
medications that youth were prescribed when entering care.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10177 Resident restraint
Section (1) The facility shall establish and follow written policy and
Description procedures specifying the use of resident restraint.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Incident 1: The youth was choked during a restraint on 4/17/2025.
Additional Allegation Incident 2: The youth was inappropriately
restrained on 4/29/2025.
6

Additional Allegation Incident 3: The youth was inappropriately
restrained on 5/5/2025.
Investigation Incident 1:
Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on May 8, 2025,
in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Complainant said she
was unsure where exactly the incident of Youth A being choked
occurred, however she believed it was on video camera.
Complainant said she has witnessed several bruises and a cut on
Youth A’s lip through Zoom meetings. Complainant did not have
additional information to provide.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on May
13, 2025. Youth A said he was placed at Saginaw Detention on
April 17, 2025. Youth A said he arrived at the facility and did not
want to take a shower. Staff 1 punched him five times in the face
causing his whole face to be bruised. Youth A said Staff 1 and
Staff 2 attempted to put him in a restraint and were holding him on
the ground. Youth A said Staff 1 had his hand on the back of
Youth A’s neck with Staff 1’s thumb on his throat causing him
difficulty breathing. Youth A said Staff 2 also put his hand on the
back of Youth A’s neck with Staff 2’s thumb on his throat causing
him difficulty breathing. Youth A said at one point during the
restraint he was lying on the ground and Staff 1 had his knee on
the side of his head holding him down. Youth A said Staff 2 also
had his knee on Youth A’s neck while he was on the floor. Youth A
said the staff made him put on a “smock” and dragged Youth A
down the hallway. Youth A said while going down the hallway he
tripped a staff, and they all went forward and someone that was
standing behind him grabbed the smock to stop his fall. He was
leaning forward being choked by the neckline of the smock. Youth
A said after he was placed in his room, he noticed he had bruises
on his arms from Staff 1 and Staff 2.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on June 17, 2025, in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 said he was the only
staff with Youth A at first and has done intakes in the past. Staff 1
asked Youth A to take a shower, and he refused. Staff 1 said he
called for assistance and Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4 and Staff 13
arrived. Staff 1 reported staff "followed procedure and policy to try
to talk to him and guide him to do the right thing." Staff 1 said he
talked to Youth A for approximately 45 minutes trying to get him to
stand up and comply. Staff 1 stated, "Everything was fine. Cool,
calm, and collected" denying ever getting upset or frustrated with
Youth A. Staff 1 said eventually he and Staff 2 placed Youth A in a
7

standing Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI) hold, with one staff on
either side of Youth A holding his arms, to escort him to his room
because he would not leave intake. Staff 1 said once Youth A was
out of the intake room, he was compliant and there were no
further issues. Staff 1 said Youth A was saying “stuff” towards the
staff, but he was not able to remember any specific statements.
Staff 1 said he recalled Youth A spitting at staff throughout the
process as well. Staff 1 denied ever cursing or saying anything to
provoke Youth A throughout the process. Staff 1 said Youth A
was from out of county and it is not uncommon for there to be
more resistance from youth from other counties. Staff 1 said he
believes all staff responded exactly how they were trained, and
they followed policy throughout this incident. Staff 1 said the
restraints done were “proper” and he did not have any concerns
with any of the staff's responses with Youth A during this incident.
Staff 1 said “we had so many staff" helping that the restraint was
effective and there was no resistance from Youth A or any
adjustments that staff had to make throughout the process. Staff
1 denied ever hitting Youth A throughout the process. Staff 1
denied Youth A having any injuries after the incident, not even
accidentally due to the restraint. Staff 1 denied Youth A ever
complained about not being able to breathe. Staff 1 confirmed
staff were able to get a smock on Youth A but denied there was a
time Youth A tripped staff or there were issues with breathing
once the smock was put on. Staff 1 denied any times his
behaviors have become excessive with any youth, stating he has
a good relationship with the youth and just try to “show them love”
when he works.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on May 21,
2025, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 said he was
called by Staff 13 to come to the intake area and assist Staff 1
with Youth A. Staff 2 said when he arrived at intake Staff 1 was
explaining the expectations and intake process to Youth A who
was being hostile and refusing to comply with directions. Staff 2
said he tried to take over talking with Youth A and it did not
change anything, and he continued to be threatening and refused
to comply with directions. Staff 2 said it was decided Youth A did
not need to complete any of the intake process and walk to his
room. Youth A still refused even that and would not move. Staff 2
said Youth A was fully dressed sitting by the shower doors and
refused to move. Staff 2 said Staff 13 said he needed to get up
and gave him the choice to walk to his room and he responded,
“fuck this nigger” and he was going to sit there all night. Staff 2
said Staff 13 gave the directive to Staff 1 and Staff 2 to escort
Youth A. Staff 2 said he once again gave Youth A the option to
8

walk on his own and Youth A said no so he and Staff 2 each took
one of Youth A’s arms and began to walk him out of intake. Staff 2
said Youth A resisted and caused them all to fall forward onto the
ground. Staff 2 said Youth A grabbed and pulled his hair and
Youth A was let go. Staff 2 said Staff 13 called for additional staff
assistance and Youth A stood up, so Staff 1 and Staff 2 placed
him in a standing hold with one of them on each side of Youth A
holding his arms. Staff 2 said he and Staff 1 began to move
forward and Youth A fell backward on to Staff 13 and then ended
up on the ground again. Staff 2 said Staff 3 arrived to assist and
took over for Staff 1. Staff 2 said Youth A was lying on his back on
the ground. Staff 2 was sitting with his knees on either side of
Youth A’s elbows with his arm on Youth A’s shoulder to secure
control of Youth A. Staff 2 said he continued to try to verbally
deescalate Youth A. However, he was very upset screaming
obscenities and racial comments. Staff 2 said he, Staff 1, Staff 3,
and Staff 13 were able to get Youth A on his feet and then he
kicked Staff 3. Staff 4 arrived to help, and they all got knocked
back to the ground due to Youth A struggling and his momentum
taking them down. Staff 2 said Staff 13 brought out a suicide
smock and he, Staff 2, Staff 3 and Staff 13 “tussled” with Youth A
to get his clothing off and got him to his underwear and got the
smock on him. Staff 2 said the thinking was the suicide smock
was heavy so might help wear Youth A out a bit so they could get
him to his room. Staff 2 said this whole process took about 20
minutes and then they finally were able to escort Youth A out of
the intake room and into the hallway. Staff 2 said Youth A fell back
once again on Staff 13 and kicked Staff 3 for a second time. Staff
2 said he and Staff 1 were able to get Youth A up on his feet by
lifting him under his arms. Staff 2 said Staff 3 took over securing
his arms and Staff 2 was working on controlling Youth A’s legs
from kicking out at staff. Staff 2 said in the process Youth A
“headbutted” him, so he stepped back. Staff 2 said Youth A finally
started to tire out and began walking down the hallway. Staff 2
said he took over for Staff 3 and he and Staff 1 were walking
Youth A. Staff 2 said Youth A hooked his legs around Staff 2’s leg
and they lowered Youth A down to his knees so he could get his
leg free. Then they stood him back up and Youth A walked with
them the rest of the way to his room. Staff 2 said Youth A walked
into his room and was released. Staff left and shut the door. Staff
2 said he debriefed with Staff 13 and then went back to his unit for
the remainder of the shift. Staff 2 said he never saw Staff 1 place
his hands around Youth A’s neck. Staff 2 said Youth A said he
could not breathe several times throughout the incident and
whenever he said that the staff would reposition, stop what they
were doing, or sit him up. Staff 2 said he never saw any staff with
9

their knees on Youth A’s neck. Staff 2 said he never saw Staff 1
punch Youth A. Staff 2 said Youth A had some scratches on his
arm and Staff 13 provided him with Band-Aids. Staff 2 denied
Youth A have any major injuries from the incident.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on June 12, 2025, in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 3 said she was called
down to the intake area and as she was walking down the
hallway, she could hear Staff 1 cussing and yelling. Staff 3 said
when she entered the room Youth A was undressed and being
held on the ground by Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 13. Staff 3 said
she told Staff 1 to be quiet and stop going back and forth with
Youth A because he was making things worse. Staff 3 said Youth
A “headbutted” Staff 2 however he continued to keep Youth A in a
proper hold. Staff 3 said Staff 1 started calling Youth A “little bitch”
and “motherfucker” over and over. Staff 3 said Staff 1 held Youth
A by the neck and punched him with a closed fist in the head at
least three times. Staff 3 said she and Staff 13 were both telling
Staff 1 to stop and he stopped hitting him but kept calling him
names. Staff 3 said Staff 13 got Youth A into the suicide smock
and Staff 1 and Staff 3 were able to stand Youth A up and move
him into the hallway. Staff 3 said as they were moving down the
hallway Youth A used his legs to wrap around Staff 3’s leg and
she was unable to move until Staff 4 arrived and helped get Youth
A’s legs off hers. Staff 3 said Youth A began to call them “niggers”
which set Staff 1 off again and he was yelling and cussing at
Youth A. Staff 3 said they were finally able to get Youth A into his
room and shut the door. Staff 3 said Youth A had been
complaining of not being able to breathe throughout the incident
however she never saw anyone restricting his airway and believes
it was just from “all the chaos”. Staff 3 said she did not see any
marks or bruises on Youth A after the incident. Staff 1 is “hard to
reach as a staff” and engages in many power struggles and verbal
arguments with youth. Staff 3 said she has never seen him
physically hurt a youth until that day when he was “acting like he
was in a street fight”. Staff 3 said her concerns about this incident
were brought up to Staff 13, the supervisor on duty that night.
Staff 3 said Director and Assistant Administrator are aware of the
concerns with Staff 1 engaging in verbal arguments with the youth
at the facility.
Staff 4 was interviewed via telephone on May 28, 2025, in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 4 said she was called
down to the intake room by Staff 13 and asked to get scissors for
Staff 13 to cut off Youth A’s pants and place him in a suicide
smock. Staff 4 said when she returned with the scissors Youth A
10

was laying on the ground on his back kicking, yelling, calling Staff
1 a “nigger”, pulling Staff 2’s hair and hitting Staff 13. Staff 4 said
she left to go do a round of checks on all the other youth and
when she got back Youth A’s pants were down to his knees and
he was still resisting and fighting against Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff
13. Staff 4 said she left to do another round of checks and when
she returned Youth A had been placed in the suicide smock. Staff
1, Staff 2, Staff 3, and Staff 13 were in the hallway. Youth A was
sitting on Staff 13’s back while Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 were
verbally trying to convince Youth A to get off Staff 13. Staff 4 said
she left for another round of checks and when she returned Youth
A was standing with Staff 2 on one side of him and Staff 3 on the
other side of him. Staff 4 said Youth A had his leg wrapped around
Staff 3’s leg and Staff 1 and Staff 13 were holding Staff 3 up and
verbally encouraging Youth A to release her leg. Staff 4 said she
once again did a round of checks and when she returned Youth A
was willingly walking and they got him into his room and shut the
door. Staff 4 said she never saw any staff hit Youth A. Staff 4
denied seeing any marks or bruises on Youth A. Staff 4 said she
never heard Youth A say he was unable to breathe.
Staff 13 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on May 13,
2025, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. A follow-up
interview was conducted face-to-face at the facility on June
17, 2025. Staff 13 said Youth A arrived at the facility on April 17,
2025. Staff 13 and Staff 1 were working with Youth A through the
intake process. Staff 13 said Youth A was “fine” throughout the
question portion of the intake process however once he was
required to shower and change his clothing, he began to refuse,
and his behaviors escalated. Staff 13 said Youth A was told he did
not have to shower and instead just asked to change into other
clothing which he continued to refuse and sat on the floor. Staff 13
said she sent Staff 2 into the shower area to assist Staff 1 in
“motivating” Youth A to complete the intake process, and she
stood outside the door. Staff 13 said Youth A continued to get
“worked up” and began to refuse to do anything but sit on the
floor. Staff 13 said she returned to the intake room and Youth A
was given several opportunities to walk to his room, even without
showering or changing his clothing, however he refused. Staff 13
said Youth A was calling names, using derogatory statements,
and racial comments towards staff. Staff 13 said Staff 1 was
“reacting” to what Youth A was saying however could not
remember exactly what Staff 1 was saying. Staff 13 said she kept
saying “stay focused” to Staff 1 throughout the situation as he was
very frustrated with Youth A. Staff 13 said she was not able to
remove Staff 1 from the situation as she needed him to help
11

control the situation. Staff 13 said Youth A was attempting to bite
and spit on her and Staff 1 and Staff 1 would “deflect” the biting
attempts and spit by moving Youth A’s face the opposite direction
with his hand. Staff 13 denied seeing Staff 1 use force on Youth
A’s face, however, could not remember if Staff 1 had an open or
closed hand when moving Youth A’s face. Staff 13 said Staff 1
and Staff 2 attempted to stand Youth A and place him in an escort
with one on each side of Youth A which resulted in him becoming
aggressive towards staff attempting to punch, kick, and bite staff.
Staff 13 said she, Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 all were attempting
to get Youth A to follow instructions. However, he refused and
continued the aggressive behaviors, so he was held in a restraint
while sitting on the floor. Staff 13 said Youth A ended up on his
back on the floor and the restraint continued with her, Staff 1, Staff
2, and Staff 3. Staff 13 said Youth A began to make comments
about hurting himself, so she got the scissors and cut the string
from his pants, removed his clothing, and placed him in a suicide
smock. Staff 13 said she, Staff 1, and Staff 2 were able to move
Youth A into the hallway and started to walk towards the units.
Youth A began to kick the staff and used his body weight to “ram”
staff into the walls. Staff 13 said Youth A stopped walking and was
“dragging his feet for a long while” as Staff 1 and Staff 2 were
walking forward moving down the hallway. Staff 13 said she was
walking behind Youth A to secure his head when needed. Staff 13
said while walking in the hallway, Staff 4 was opening the doors
they needed to pass through while Staff 1 and Staff 2 were on
either side of Youth A, and she was walking behind them. Staff 13
said Staff 3 switched with Staff 1 and held one of Youth A’s arms
and Staff 1 began walking behind them. Staff 13 said at one point
Youth A fell forward and she grabbed his smock to prevent him
from falling. Staff 13 denied Youth A ever choking or saying he
could not breathe when he fell, noting the smock is loose and
Velcro is in place. Staff 13 said the entire restraint took “too long”
and Youth A was “threatening to get everyone fired” the entire
time. Staff 13 said she was not aware of any injuries Youth A
obtained during the restraint and reported the restraint was done
per CPI restraint training. Staff 13 said once Youth A was placed
in his room, he ripped a long string off his mattress and wrapped it
around his arm. Staff 13 said she had to go into his room and use
a nail clipper in order to remove the string. Staff 13 said Youth A
broke tiles and due to the self-harm issues, he was moved to
another room for his own safety. Staff 13 said she has had to talk
to Staff 1 on “several occasions” for taking what youth say to him
